page.title: 06 Danes'Hill
page.content: In 1066 a Danish invasion force sailed up the River Ouse and landed at nearby Riccall. Local tradition claims that, after their defeat at Stamford Bridge, Danish warriors were buried under a mound in Skipwith Common. The truth lies further back in time, as it is probably a burial ground of the Ancient Briton's.There are several tumuli dotted around Skipwith Common. In 1754 a Doctor Burton opened some tumuli. In the centre of one of the largest he found an almost perfect human skeleton, locals call the hill by different names. Apart from Big Hill (the rest of the land is very flat), one such name is King Rudding Hill. Some say a King Rudding is buried underneath. Gun Hill and Target Hill are two local names connected with wartime activities in the area
